sections.title: The Norman Connection
sections.content: English and French share roughly 27% of their vocabulary because of the Norman conquest of England in 1066. Thousands of English words came from French. With a few simple suffix-swap rules, you can instantly recognize and use thousands of French words.

sections.title: Key Suffix Patterns
sections.content: These 16 patterns convert English words to French with 80-95% accuracy. For example: -tion stays -tion (nation, information), -ty becomes -te (university -> universite), -ic becomes -ique (music -> musique), -ous becomes -eux/-euse (famous -> fameux).

sections.title: Instant Vocabulary Hack
sections.content: With just these 16 patterns, you can recognize 3,000-5,000 French words immediately. When you encounter a new English word with one of these endings, try the French version - you'll be right 80%+ of the time.

title: Pronunciation Rules
subtitle: Decode French spelling with consistent rules

sections.title: The 3 Golden Rules
sections.content: 1) Silent final consonants - most consonants at the end are silent (except CaReFuL: C, R, F, L). 2) Stress is ALWAYS on the last syllable. 3) Nasal vowels - vowel + N/M (with no vowel after) becomes nasal.

sections.title: Vowel Sounds
sections.content: French vowels have consistent sounds: ou = 'oo', oi = 'wah', ai/ei = 'eh', au/eau = 'oh', e (accent aigu) = 'ay', e (accent grave) = 'eh'.

sections.title: Nasal Vowels
sections.content: These make French sound French. an/am/en/em = nasalized 'ah', on/om = nasalized 'oh', in/im/ain = nasalized short 'ah'. Trick: if vowel+N/M is followed by another vowel or doubled N/M, it's NOT nasal.

sections.title: Consonant Tricks
sections.content: Key consonant differences: ch = 'sh', j = 'zh', qu = 'k' (never 'kw'), h is ALWAYS silent, r is guttural (back of throat), th = just 't'.

sections.title: The CaReFuL Rule
sections.content: Most final consonants are silent, but C, R, F, L are usually pronounced. Remember: CaReFuL. Examples: avec (a-VEK), pour (POOR), chef (SHEF), animal (a-nee-MAL).

title: Gender Rules
subtitle: Guess noun gender correctly 80%+ of the time

sections.title: Feminine Endings
sections.content: These endings are almost always feminine (la): -tion/-sion (~99%), -te (~99%), -ee (~99%), -ure (~95%), -ence/-ance (~95%), -ie (~95%), -ette/-elle (~95%), -ise/-aise (~95%).

sections.title: Masculine Endings
sections.content: These endings are almost always masculine (le): -age (~90%), -ment (~99%), -isme (~99%), -eau (~99%), -oir (~95%), -et (~95%). Consonant endings are ~65-70% masculine.

sections.title: Gender Survival Strategy
sections.content: Always learn gender WITH the word: never learn 'maison' alone - learn 'la maison'. When in doubt, the -tion/-sion/-te/-ure patterns cover HUNDREDS of words. At NCLC 5, small gender errors won't fail you.

title: Verb Conjugation Shortcuts
subtitle: Master spoken French with just 30 verbs

sections.title: The 80/20 Verbs
sections.content: For NCLC 5 conversation, you need about 30 verbs covering 80%+ of daily situations: etre, avoir, faire, aller, venir, pouvoir, vouloir, devoir, savoir, dire, parler, prendre, voir, mettre, donner, and more.

sections.title: The Spoken French Shortcut
sections.content: For ALL regular -er verbs (80%+ of French verbs), je, tu, and il/elle forms are pronounced IDENTICALLY. And ils/elles -ent is completely silent! So in spoken French, you really only learn 3 sounds: the stem, -ons, and -ez.

examples.french: je parle / tu parles / il parle

sections.title: -ER Verb Pattern
sections.content: 80% of French verbs end in -er: je -e, tu -es, il/elle -e, nous -ons, vous -ez, ils/elles -ent. Only 3 distinct sounds in speech!

sections.title: Future Tense Cheat
sections.content: Instead of learning formal future tense, use aller + infinitive (just like English 'going to'): Je vais manger = I'm going to eat. 100% acceptable at NCLC 5.

sections.title: Past Tense Cheat
sections.content: Passe compose formula: Subject + avoir + past participle. Past participle shortcuts: -er -> -e, -ir -> -i, -re -> -u. About 15 'DR. MRS. VANDERTRAMP' verbs use etre instead.

sections.title: Negation: Sandwich the Verb
sections.content: Put NE...PAS around the conjugated verb. In spoken French, 'ne' is almost always dropped. For TEF, use both ne...pas to be safe.

sections.title: Asking Questions: 3 Ways
sections.content: 1) Rising intonation (easiest, used 90% of time): Tu parles francais? 2) Est-ce que (medium): Est-ce que tu parles francais? 3) Inversion (formal): Parles-tu francais?

sections.title: Question Words
sections.content: Qui (Who), Quoi/Que (What), Ou (Where), Quand (When), Pourquoi (Why), Comment (How), Combien (How much/many).

sections.title: Articles
sections.content: French ALWAYS uses articles: le/la/les (the), un/une/des (a/some). Before vowels: l'. Key difference: French uses 'des' where English uses nothing. 'I have cats' = 'J'ai des chats'.

sections.title: Mandatory Contractions
sections.content: de+le=du, de+les=des, a+le=au, a+les=aux. These are MANDATORY - never say 'de le' or 'a le'. Also: je+vowel=j', ne+vowel=n'.

sections.title: Numbers 1-69
sections.content: Numbers 0-69 are straightforward. Key ones: 0-16 have unique names, 17-19 use dix-sept/dix-huit/dix-neuf, 20-69 follow pattern (vingt, trente, quarante, cinquante, soixante) with 'et un' for 21/31/41/51/61.

sections.title: Numbers 70-99: The Math Part
sections.content: 70 = soixante-dix (60+10), 80 = quatre-vingts (4x20), 90 = quatre-vingt-dix (4x20+10). Belgian/Swiss French is simpler: septante, huitante/octante, nonante.

sections.title: Dangerous False Friends
sections.content: These French words LOOK like English words but mean something completely different. Getting these wrong can be embarrassing or worse!

sections.title: Safe Alternatives
sections.content: For each false friend, learn the correct word: excited = enthousiaste, library = bibliotheque, actually = en fait, to attend = assister, to rest = se reposer.

sections.title: Mandatory Liaisons
sections.content: Liaison is when a normally silent final consonant is pronounced because the next word starts with a vowel. Mandatory between: article+noun, pronoun+verb, adjective+noun, after prepositions.

sections.title: Liaison Sound Changes
sections.content: In liaison: s/x become Z, d becomes T, n stays N, t stays T. These sound changes are consistent and predictable.

sections.title: Elision
sections.content: When a short word ending in -e meets a word starting with a vowel, the -e drops and becomes an apostrophe. This is MANDATORY: le+ami = l'ami, je+ai = j'ai, de+eau = d'eau.

sections.title: Basic Greetings
sections.content: Essential greetings, introductions, and polite phrases that you'll use every day.

sections.title: Communication Lifelines
sections.content: These phrases save you when you're struggling to communicate. Your #1 safety phrase: Je ne comprends pas (I don't understand).

sections.title: Daily Life & Work
sections.content: Phrases for talking about yourself, your work, and expressing opinions.

sections.title: Filler Words
sections.content: Silence kills your score. Use fillers to buy thinking time: Alors... (So...), Bon... (Well...), En fait... (Actually...), Comment dire... (How to say...), Par exemple... (For example...).

sections.title: Opinion Structures
sections.content: The TEF asks you to express opinions. Use: Je pense que... parce que..., A mon avis..., D'un cote... de l'autre cote..., En conclusion...

examples.english: On one hand... on the other hand...

sections.title: Recovery Strategies
sections.content: The #1 TEF secret: Keep talking! Forgot a word? Describe it. Made a mistake? Self-correct: 'Non, pardon, je veux dire...' Don't understand? Ask to rephrase. NEVER go silent.

examples.english: It's a thing that... (forgot a word)
